artefact.overview:
You may need to tell DVLA if you've had a stroke - download the correct form if you need to let them know

When to tell DVLA if you've had a stroke or TIA (mini-stroke), forms to fill in and send if you need to inform DVLA
artefact.body:
You may need to tell DVLA if you’ve had a stroke.

You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don’t tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you’re involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted.

Car or motorcycle licence

You only need to tell DVLA if you’re still having problems 1 month after the stroke. If you are, fill in form STR1 and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

Download the DVLA’s advice leaflet ‘TIA1’ to find out if you need to tell them about your stroke.

Download ‘TIA1 - Car or motorcycle drivers who have had a stroke or transient ischaemic attack (TIA)’ (PDF, 260KB)

If you do need to tell DVLA, fill in form STR1 and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

Download ‘STR1 - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 285KB)

Bus, coach or lorry driver licence

You must tell DVLA if you’ve had a stroke (or TIA). Fill in form STR1V and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

Download ‘STR1V - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 315KB)
